awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The interplay between fluctuating selection on symbionts and life cycle evolution in sap-sucking insects
awd_abstract_narration:
Insects that feed on the sap of their host plants, including many crop and forest pests, have within them beneficial bacteria that provide the insects with essential nutrients that are missing from their diet. This research quantifies how the properties of those bacteria have been affected by evolutionary changes in insect diets; it further explores the role that the bacteria have played in how the insects use new host plants and in the insect's life cycle. This knowledge is important because it highlights bacteria as hidden players in major aspects of insect ecology and evolution. Information from this project may also assist in the control of several forest pest insects. This project will provide training for graduate students, undergraduates, and high-school students, including individuals from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences, and will promote public events to enhance scientific literacy and appreciation for research.

This project studies Adelgidae insects that feed on conifer trees, and their dual symbionts. It tests the hypothesis that fluctuating demands for nutrient provisioning in insects has led to symbiont replacements, which in turn have precipitated new host-plant acquisitions and life-cycle complexity. Specific objectives include (1) establishing a family-wide pattern of the unusual role allocations between dual symbionts; (2) quantifying the contributions of symbionts and insect hosts to nutrient provisioning as a measure of adjustment to nutrient availability; (3) quantifying rates of evolution in symbiont genomes under different insect feeding modes. These objectives will be accomplished through DNA and RNA sequencing of symbiont genomes and expressed insect genes that support symbiont functions.

por.por_cntn:
Insects that feed upon plant sap contain beneficial bacteria that provide insects with nutrients that are lacking from the plant sap diet and are essential for survival and reproduction. This research focuses upon adelgids, plant-sap feeding insects of conifers, some of which are key forest pests that alternate between different types of conifers that vary in their nutritional quality. The identity and genetic capacity of microbes producing nutrients was characterized for a diversity of adelgid species, demonstrating rapid replacements of microbes that have relationships with these insects; a pattern that is unusual for sap-feeding insects. The first genome sequence of an adelgid was generated and serves as an important reference for further studies of gene activity. Ongoing research is quantifying how properties of bacterial microbes and adelgids are affected by alternating conifer host plants representing variation in insect diets. Overall research outcomes demonstrate how bacteria in sap-feeding insects act as hidden players in insect ecology and evolution. Results from funded research was published in three peer-reviewed publications to date, and were presented at discipline-specific conferences ranging in scope from regional to international. Funding from this grant supported the training of two graduate students and two undergraduate students to become globally competitive scientists, including students who are underrepresented in science. The project contributed to public outreach by educating middle-school students about research on insects and their microbes.
